ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: also a virtual lecture
Live virtual lecture combined with virtual discussion
Combination of live seminar/lecture
Combination of lecture and seminar-style discussion.
Combination of live virtual lecture and virtual seminar and discussion.
Mix between virtual seminar and lecture, i.e. both lecture and seminar components
A combination of lecture and discussion.
Seminar/lecture hybrid
live virtual lecture + in-class discussion sections
We were in a seminar of 30 people in which the professor lectured at some points, but at others, we broke in half into smaller sections with TAs.
live seminar with built-in time for small group discussions
Our classes consisted of live lectures in the first half followed by class discussion by students in the second half.
There were not any other model of learning.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the origins of American government and politics, civil rights and liberties, Congress, the President, the Supreme Court, and many other facets of American politics such as the media and polarization.
How to read political science research papers.
Good introduction to American politics, the structure of American government, and how the public's understanding of American politics is shaped by third parties such as the media.
An introduction to the american political system
Broad introduction to the structure of American politics and political science research.

I gained a solid overview of the American political system, ranging from the framers and the constitution to voting preferences, the judiciary, and current topics in politics (dating behavior, race, etc.). Also worked on essay writing. Overall, developed some good insights on how the American Political system works and was exposed to some political science through the readings and discussions on the readings.
Basic understanding of foundations of American government and politics

This course is not about analyzing current political issues, but rather understanding the mechanisms and institutional designs of the American political system. A huge emphasis on collective action problems and how they relate to politics.
A survey course about how our government functions

I did not have a foundation in American politics, as I had taken AP United States History in high school but not AP United States Government. I was glad that I took this class during an election year and felt that I learned very practical topics that allowed me to understand our political system even better at a time that I needed to. I was able to understand topics that I had a foundational amount of knowledge on at a deeper level and think that that will be very useful for the rest of my life.
Fundamentals of American Politics.
Greater knowledge in American politics, improved research and writing skills
I learned how think more deeply, critically, and thoroughly about political science puzzles.
I read a lot of seminal works on political science and filled in some important gaps in my fundamental understanding of the American government.
Application of historical concepts and ideals to current events and the way our political system currently works.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The teacher is very nice and she's helpful with her assignments. Barely any written assignments.
Weaknesses: Assigned at least 200 pages of reading a night and then picked a random reading to have a quiz on. Also, assigned a fifteen page group paper over zoom as the final project which was incredibly hard. Workload was not manageable and I couldn't read them to learn just had to read them to complete them.

This is a great introduction to American politics if you have never had any sort of exposure at all because it moves VERY fast. You are not expected to memorize or learn every single thing covered in the textbooks, lectures, and readings, but knowing the general gist of it all is definitely essential to writing papers and actually understanding the course. Strengths: Professor Kinane is extremely kind, enthusiastic and loves to talk to her students, lectures in class go over textbook material and is very helpful in consolidating information. Weaknesses: course moves VERY fast
Prof. Kinane is the biggest strength
Strengths was that it's very well organized. However, it almost seems like there is too much material and reading for one semester, making it hard to focus on a singular topic or entirely learn.

Strengths: Professor Kinane was the biggest strength. She was enthusiastic and engaging. This course is a good introduction to American politics if you have no background in the subject, though a lot of the material felt pretty familiar and we didn't go very in depth for a lot of it. The TAs were fantastic and provided very detailed feedback on essays. The course really is set up for students to succeed. Weaknesses: I would have liked to have talked more about contemporary political events in the US. Although it was nice to get an introduction to research in the field, the papers we read had predictable results and were not particularly engaging (apart from the ones we read in the last week which were very interesting). The workload was more than expected (often 100-150 pages/week of textbook readings and research papers)

This course was an interesting one. Professor Kinane is a really good and engaging lecturer, but I felt as if the discussions in the course weren't that strong--that was due to the zoom classroom experience. Focusing so much of the course during a zoom year on discussions made the seminars, at some times, feel dry. However, the discussions were sometimes interesting. Also, I feel like a lot of information is given to us in the course that isn't deeply explored or even tested. For example, we only had two big assignments: two essays and one short answer question packet. While we were tested on some of the topics, the majority were not revisited in other units, unless they had clear connections through the readings. Being more formally tested on the topics would allow us to retain the information better.

Covers a lot of topics, good introductory course (but also means it doesn't go into much depth on each topic). Also, the final being a group project was definitely a weakness because group projects are rarely enjoyable

Strengths: engaging, interesting content presented in a great way. 

Weaknesses: perhaps it was the design of the course (or choosing the less experienced section), but some of the content seemed to be rather basic.

Strengths: Very good slides, Professor Kinane was very energetic, and I thought my TA was very helpful
Weaknesses: Too broad, often feels like an AP Government course; readings were often long and tedious

I thought that the course was very well organized. The professor did a very good job splitting the course between her lecturing and our sections, and I found it very engaging. It was easy for me to speak up during the class and I felt that both she and the TAs strongly encouraged our learning.
Course is very interactive and tailored in the best interest of learning.
Loved smaller breakout room seminars, but discussions sessions couldve been more productive in small groups.
Strengths - pace of the course was super conducive to learning material well. Not too fast! Weekly structure was also helpful with understanding how material builds and relates to the larger picture.

Strengths: I liked all of the readings in the course, and the TAs were very helpful. Weaknesses: lectures were done by reading off of black and white slides, which was not always very engaging. Discussions were a bit too heavily moderated.

The reading quizzes were a strength because they kept me accountable for work outside of class.  I would have liked to discuss current events more as they came up through the semester (like the new supreme court nomination and election) but the syllabus did not allow for much deviation.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: She said she redesigned the whole class for the pandemic but I think she made it ten times harder which makes no sense. The discussion parts were not fun at all.
The professor and teaching fellows were very understanding towards the circumstances, and the assignments were not as taxing as they could've been.

Overall, the lectures and assignments worked great. Discussions weren't that great, and that was due to zoom. Focusing so much on the discussion was likely the culprit, but the switch in the structure after feedback during the midterm was awesome. Focusing on people choosing to participate, and having small discussion groups made it easier for others who usually didn't participate in the big discussion to have a place to participate with the TFs. Maybe having one day (Friday) be the only discussion day with it split 50/50 between TF and the larger group would allow for better and more engaging discussions.
Would have preferred more discussion opportunities, either with a dedicated section on Fridays or just more time to discuss in class.

The course was very dynamic even over Zoom. I thought that the lectures were very engaging and that the sections were very interactive. The Canvas page was always well updated, and I thought that despite the pandemic, the course functioned extremely well.
Class discussions made the course interactive and helped facilitate learning.
seminar style set up was super helpful to learning material and provided time to ask questions about unclear material
I liked the use of breakout rooms and that the lecture slides were made available for access outside of class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes; if you don't already know the basics of American government, this course does a great job of explaining the history behind our government and discussing current issues that face American politics.
No, at least not during the pandemic. I think during in person class it would be great.

Yes if you want a good foundation in American politics. As an international student, I would recommend it to other international students because it helps to understand politics and the Yale political echo-chamber. Prof Kinane is very enthusiastic and high-energy. However, this course moves FAST. you do not NEED to do the readings in-depth, but it definitely helps. There is a LOT of reading in this class, and there are weekly quizzes and discussions on it so you can't get away without doing any reading.
I would recommend this course to any student who wants an introduction to the American governmental system.
Yes, if they have no politics background. Material is very introductory and you leave with a good understanding of American politics. Professor Kinane is engaging and enthusiastic.

Yes, I would recommend the course if you haven't taken a PLSC course in high school and are thinking of majoring in PLSC at Yale. This course introduces you to PLSC with an analysis of political science readings and some brief introductions to theory. This is also a good course if you are interested in an overview of the American Political System.
If you're interested in american politics, yes.
I was interested in political science and I wanted to start off with a foundational course. If you are not required to take this course I wouldn't recommend it.
Yes, you will learn a lot and it doesn't eat up too much of your mental energy. Politics apply to a lot more of our lives than you would think, and this class really highlights that.
yes, if you did not take AP Gov.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student looking to gain a foundation in American politics. I found the course to be very well organized and fair, and I felt that I learned a large amount of material in a relatively stress free way. I also really enjoyed the professor and the TAs and thought that they structured the class phenomenally.
I would recommend this course to another student looking for an overview of major concepts of American politics.
Yes

definitely! This course is a perfect first step for laying foundation to pursing a degree and even a career in political science. Great pace, helpful organization of material, knowledgeable and passionate professor.
This course provided a good basic introduction to the study of American politics. I would recommend it to someone who is casually interested, but not someone who already has a grasp on the subject.
I would recommend this course to another student for gaining baseline knowledge about Americas political systems.
